description: Common clinical reasoning errors (traps) organized by HOAC step, with detection cues and coaching responses
source: Compiled from ESP teaching experience and AI in CR education research (Shen 2025, Wu 2025)

general.name: Premature Closure
general.description: Accepting the first hypothesis without considering alternatives
general.example: Immediately concluding 'disc herniation' based on leg pain without considering other causes
general.coaching_response: You've identified one possible explanation. What alternative mechanisms could also explain these findings?
general.prevention_strategy: Always require at least 2 competing hypotheses for major problems

general.name: Confirmation Bias
general.description: Seeking or interpreting information to confirm initial hypothesis while ignoring contradictory evidence
detection_cues: Dismissing findings that don't fit hypothesis
general.example: Ignoring negative neurological signs while emphasizing pain patterns that support radiculopathy hypothesis
general.coaching_response: I notice you haven't addressed [contradictory finding]. How does this fit with your hypothesis?
general.prevention_strategy: Explicitly ask: 'What finding here might challenge your hypothesis?'

general.name: Anchoring Bias
general.description: Over-relying on initial information and failing to adjust reasoning based on new data
detection_cues: Returning to initial impression despite new information
general.example: Continuing to focus on 'muscle strain' mentioned by GP despite findings suggesting different mechanism
general.coaching_response: The referral mentioned [X], but your findings suggest [Y]. How should we integrate this new information?
general.prevention_strategy: Treat referral diagnosis as hypothesis to test, not confirmed truth

step_1.name: Psychosocial Factor Dismissal
step_1.description: Rushing past or dismissing psychosocial context as less important than biomedical factors
detection_cues: Brief mention of work/life without exploration
step_1.example: Noting 'works in office' without exploring work stress, deadline pressure, or fear-avoidance
step_1.coaching_response: You've noted the occupation. How might their work demands, stress, or beliefs about the condition affect prognosis?
step_1.prevention_strategy: Systematically address psychosocial factors using structured screening

step_1.name: Red Flag Assumption
step_1.description: Assuming red flags are absent without systematic screening
detection_cues: No mention of red flag screening
step_1.example: Proceeding to problem list without confirming absence of cauda equina symptoms, unexplained weight loss, or night pain
step_1.coaching_response: Before we proceed, have we ruled out red flags? What specific safety features have we screened for?
step_1.prevention_strategy: Always document red flag screening, even when negative

step_2.name: Diagnosis as Problem
step_2.description: Stating a medical diagnosis instead of a functional problem
detection_cues: Problem statement is a diagnosis (e.g., 'LBP', 'rotator cuff tear')
ICF coding at diagnosis level rather than activity/participation
step_2.example: 'The problem is non-specific low back pain' instead of 'Unable to sit through work meetings'
step_2.coaching_response: That's a diagnosis, not a functional problem. If this condition resolved, what would the patient be able to DO that they can't do now?
step_2.prevention_strategy: Require all PIPs to start with 'Unable to...' or 'Difficulty with...'

step_2.name: Impairment-Only Problem List
step_2.description: Listing only body function impairments without connecting to activity limitations
detection_cues: Problems are all at b-code level
step_2.example: Problem list: 1) Reduced ROM, 2) Muscle weakness, 3) Joint stiffness
step_2.coaching_response: These are impairments. How do they affect what the patient does in daily life? What can't they do because of these impairments?
step_2.prevention_strategy: Start with PIPs (patient perspective), then link NPIPs to them

step_2.name: Non-Testable Hypothesis
step_2.description: Forming hypotheses that cannot be confirmed or refuted through assessment
step_2.example: 'The pain is caused by tissue damage' - how would you test this?
step_2.coaching_response: How would you test this hypothesis? What finding would make you reconsider it?
step_2.prevention_strategy: Every hypothesis must include: What test? What expected result? What would change your mind?

step_2.name: Single Mediator for All Problems
step_2.description: Applying one mediator (e.g., 'core weakness') to explain all problems
detection_cues: Same mediator appears in multiple hypotheses
step_2.example: 'Core weakness' as mediator for sitting intolerance, walking difficulty, and lifting problems
step_2.coaching_response: You've used the same mediator for several problems. Could there be different mechanisms at play? Why this mediator over alternatives?
step_2.prevention_strategy: Consider mediators specific to each problem's characteristics

step_3.name: Standard Test Battery
step_3.description: Selecting tests because they are 'standard' rather than hypothesis-driven
step_3.example: Adding goniometry, manual muscle testing, and special tests 'because we always do them'
step_3.coaching_response: For each of these tests, can you tell me which hypothesis it helps you evaluate?
step_3.prevention_strategy: Link every test to a specific hypothesis before including it

step_3.name: Test Without Decision Consequence
step_3.description: Including tests that won't actually change clinical decisions
detection_cues: Would proceed same way regardless of result
step_3.example: Measuring ROM 'to have a baseline' without specifying how it affects treatment
step_3.coaching_response: What would you do differently if this test is positive versus negative?
step_3.prevention_strategy: Specify decision rules for each test before performing it

step_5.name: Intervention Described as Goal
step_5.description: Setting goals that describe what will be done rather than what will be achieved
detection_cues: Focus on doing rather than achieving
step_5.example: 'Patient will perform 3x10 squats' instead of 'Patient will climb stairs without pain'
step_5.coaching_response: That sounds like an intervention, not a goal. What functional OUTCOME would performing squats lead to?
step_5.prevention_strategy: Goals should describe patient function, not therapist actions

step_5.name: Goal Only at Impairment Level
step_5.description: Setting goals at body function level without connection to activities
step_5.example: 'Achieve 90 degrees knee flexion' without connecting to functional need
step_5.coaching_response: Why does the patient need this ROM? What will they be able to do with 90 degrees that they can't do now?
step_5.prevention_strategy: Long-term goals must be at participation level; short-term goals connect to them

step_6.name: Fixed Protocol Without Adaptation
step_6.description: Prescribing a set program without criteria for progression or modification
step_6.example: 'Exercise 3x/week for 6 weeks' with no mention of when/how to progress
step_6.coaching_response: What result would tell you this plan is working and ready for progression? What would tell you it's not working?
step_6.prevention_strategy: Every intervention needs progression, regression, and exit criteria

step_6.name: Guideline Name-Dropping
step_6.description: Citing a guideline without actually applying its recommendations
step_6.example: 'KNGF recommends exercise' without specifying which exercise, what dose, or which recommendation
step_6.coaching_response: Which specific recommendation from the guideline applies here? What does it say about dosage and progression?
step_6.prevention_strategy: Quote specific guideline recommendations and apply them explicitly

step_7.name: Vague Re-evaluation Plan
step_7.description: Stating need for re-evaluation without specifying when, how, or what would trigger change
detection_cues: No decision rules for plan modification
step_7.coaching_response: When specifically will you reassess? What result would make you modify the plan?
step_7.prevention_strategy: Specify exact timeline and decision criteria before starting treatment

step_7.name: Overconfidence in Reasoning
step_7.description: Expressing certainty without acknowledging limitations or alternatives
step_7.example: 'This is definitely a motor control problem' without acknowledging other possibilities
step_7.coaching_response: What might you be wrong about? What would change your mind?
step_7.prevention_strategy: Always identify at least one assumption that could be wrong

before_step_2: Have I systematically screened for red flags?
before_step_3: Is each problem at activity/participation level?
Do I have competing hypotheses for major problems?
Is each mediator specific and testable?
before_step_4: Is each test linked to a hypothesis?
Have I specified what I'll do based on each result?
before_step_5: Have I addressed all findings, including contradictory ones?
Am I willing to revise my hypothesis if needed?
before_step_6: Is my long-term goal at participation level?
Do short-term goals connect to long-term goal?
before_step_7: Have I specified progression and exit criteria?
Does my intervention target my identified mediators?
final_check: Have I specified when and how to reassess?
What might I be wrong about?
